segments.text: You don't think that Truman then had much knowledge about the situation?
Well, if we think back there, he inherited an awful lot of things in a mighty short time.
On a world scale in just a day.
Things going on in that particular theater at that time were, I'm sure, not his top priorities by any means.
So I don't really blame the Truman administration, but all of the smoke was there and building on up to the McCarthy-Bearer problem.
Were there particular senators or congressmen, though, that you would place some of the blame on, just your own personal opinion?
Oh, hell yeah.
Sure, sure.
There are.
I need to look at that a little more closely before I go start naming names.
Okay, fine.
But, yes, there had to be.
Because you were right there on the spot, and I was wondering what you and your men felt was going on.
Or you had just come back from China, and I was wondering what Brigadier General would think when he came back to America and saw what was going on with the Nationalist Army over there.
Well, it just about killed me, I can tell you that.
Because I knew those people, and we had worked hard to move them.
When you start flying a division, 1,100, 1,200 miles, I'm putting it down.
That gets to be a really rough job, and we flew almost half a million troops.
So we're not talking about peanuts.
We're talking about a big deal.
I wish I came back here to the joint staff.
I was senior air planner on the Joint Chiefs of Staff in Washington when I came from this job.
And that's when all that was happening over there.
So it was a little hard to tell you.
How about a quote while we rest?
All right, fine.
Let's have a quote.
Okay, now let's continue.
On February 46, you went back to the United States, and at that time you were a general.
about how you learned that you were appointed a general?
Yes.

When I, while I was in India, and actually in headquarters in Calcutta, General Stratmire had recommended that I be promoted to Brigadier General, and forwarded this out through, you know, Stilwell Theater and on back to Washington.
And it seemed that things were going on all right.
But General Cure, who was Air Staff A-5 here in Washington, which was Assistant Chief for Air Staff Plans, passed through India.
and stopped and talked to me.
Of course, planning was one of my functions there.
And we talked at length about plans.
We had worked together in the years before that and knew each other very well.
I told him about a plan that I was working on and my planner was working on.
in which we really made CBI an air theater.
And about the only thing that we used ground forces for was to guard the ports and air drones and a few things and we carried the war by air.
And this was just a draft plan that we were working on.
But he said, how about letting me have a copy of it?
So I did.
I didn't see any problem about that.
On his way back to Washington, after he finished his other business over there, he read the plan and he thought it had quite a bit of merit to it.
So he took it and gave it to General Handy.
General Handy was
head of the operations division of the War Department General Staff.
A really fine, wonderful man.
And General Handy liked that plan.
And for some reason he asked General Stilwell about some things that were contained in that plan.
And of course General Stilwell knew a damn thing
So, I got called out of bed one night about two o'clock in the morning by General Stratt.
I was living in, we were all living in the same house in the compound.
He stood me up in my pajamas and really dressed me down like a corporal.
that John Stilwell had called him and just absolutely raised hell with him and told him to get his ass down to Stilwell's headquarters down in downtown Calcutta.

So, and he, of course, didn't know a damn thing about it, and he went down there and found out that Stilwell was mad because this plan had gotten back into Washington when he didn't know anything about it.
Well, I hadn't tried to undercut anybody or anything else.
It was just that I had it in draft.
Larry wanted to see it, I let him have it, and then it got back here.
But still weren't wearing it back here anyway until John Marshall told me to take my name off the lip.
So something had to be done in a pretty quick hurry.
I got hold of Larry Cuter, told him what had happened.
So he went then to see John McNorney, who was General Marshall's deputy.
And John McNorney looked into it and got the facts one talk with General Handy.
So when the subject came up with General Marshall, John McNorney took my side of the cake.
John Marshall knew me too, and when all the controversy, the chatter was over there, he just pushed it over the side of his desk and kept on moving.
And it went on, it went on through.
If John McNarney hadn't been able to
be there, know the facts, and say what happened, or I probably would have just been pulled from that lift.
And of course I never would have gotten back on any lift.
So you were really delighted then when you learned that you were going to receive a star?
Oh yes.
I guess you never know the significance of a little thing.
While I was in
in Cairo at the Sexton Conference.
In the planning side of the house, I had some contact with John Handy, who was the top plan for the War Department and for the Joint Chiefs of Staff at that time.
And I told him about some things in India, and particularly having to do with the Burma Road, and how we might could
do a better, better approach there.
Well, he thought enough of it that he asked General Marshall and General Arnold to have lunch with us that day in the Manor House and at the Pyramids in Carroll where we were.
But they did, and I laid out my plan on the table.
General Arnold said, I believe it, I think it's right.
I have fought the problem all the way to the top twice, I've lost it, and I'm not going to fight it anymore.
We've got a plan to do it, let's follow the plan.
But General Marshall remembered my presentation of the thing.
General Marshall
A wonderful man, a really wonderful man.
I don't know when I've ever known anybody, ever been around anyone at that time.
I was so impressed with John Marshall.
Why do you say that?
He was big, really big.
Thought big, acted big.
but with every ounce of compassion, integrity, kindness, love, and patriotism that anyone could have.
Just a wonderful man.
Do you remember later on in his life when Senator McCarthy labeled him
Either a stooge or a traitor for the Communists?
Yes, I do.
What was your response?
I almost feel obligated to kill anybody that we categorize them that way.
I mean, I feel that strongly about it.
I didn't agree with what General Marshall did in his capacity as the peacemaker over there.
But, I didn't have the instructions that General Marshall had when he went over there, either.
To China?
Yeah.
I think what General Marshall did over there, he did pursuant to the instructions that he had when he went there.
And as I said, with the China lobby and whatnot back in the United States, it was during that same time that these supplies didn't get there.
General Marshall was not soft on any communism or anything else that was a threat to America's freedom, and he knew damn well communism was such a threat.
He would be the last thing on his agenda, I tell you.
After the Second World War, some people, some officers were reduced when one, or sometimes even two, but especially one grade in the rank.
Were you concerned that you might be reduced down to colonel?
Well, yes, I was concerned, since with one exception I was the youngest general officer that I knew of.
I think I was the youngest.
How old were you?
Let's see, I guess I was 34 by that time.
So, you became a Brigadier General at age 34?
That is incredibly young.
And there was one officer, and he actually was over in China, who was made a general up to, I think he was 28, Casey Vincent.
And he came back to the States and was reduced back to town.
So I think I was the youngest.
And I knew many others that were being reduced.
You could say one or two, two grades.
And sure, I was concerned, but what the hell, you couldn't do anything about it anyway, except the best you could, so I just didn't worry about it.
And the job that I was given when I got back here was a proper job for a Brigadier General, and so the Air Force left me in that grade and pushed me into that job.
At that time when you returned to the United States, this was a period of heavy demobilization and a lot of people were getting out and getting into civilian life.
Did you ever consider going, after the war, going into civilian life?
No.
After I got my, after I was accepted a regular commission in 1938, I determined then that I was going to make a career out of the Air Force and I just
Quit worrying about the other things.
Okay, now let's turn to your job that you held for three years, February 1946 to June 1949, the air planner for the Joint Strategic Plans Group for the JCS.
The Joint Chiefs of Staff had three groups.
at that time.
The Joint Chiefs of Staff were relatively new then, just hadn't started functioning in the war.
The Joint Strategic Plans Group, the Joint Logistics Group, and the Joint Strategic Survey Committee.
This Joint Strategic Survey Committee was a group of Army, Navy, and Air Force and Marine officers, very senior officers,
and they reviewed very large worldwide problems and prepared positions for the chiefs on those.
The Joint Strategic Plans Group prepared, number one, war plans for future use, and also
plans on any current or foreseeable situation requiring a military position by the Joint Chiefs.
One of the first things that I started working on, as a matter of fact was already in the mill when I got there,
The plan for the trusteeship of the Pacific Islands, where some of the islands were strategic trusteeships, and well it's a very large, very large problem, a very large paper.
And it was one that I spent an awful lot of the early months working on.
Like areas like Tarawa and some of those?
Some of those were British islands too, weren't they?
Yes, some were British, some were German, some French, all kinds.
What we did was really kind of whip them all together, give them the closest thing, usually give them to independence, and yet retain the kind of entree to them that we would need to
to defend them as well as take care of our own security in the Pacific.
So they all became a part of a large trusteeship, which we proposed we would be the trustees.
And then we...
designated some of them, particularly important ones, as strategic trusteeships in which the right was recognized to conduct military operations and build military facilities and this sort of thing.
Then you had to set up a governing mechanism for that.
I'm still very proud of the whole plan, except for one thing,
And like we do with the poor people in the United States, anytime we want to help them, we set up a plan that takes care of them.
And as soon as you start taking care of somebody, he becomes a ward, and then he breeds more wards.
And the first thing you know, you're up to your ears in a welfare kind of a situation.
And we were so good to all the peoples of the trusteeship, they have become wards, and now they're costing us a lot of money for not much return.
I'm not happy about that aspect of it, but everything else I am a bit happy about.
How do you think we could have resolved that problem differently?
About there being wards, you mean?
Yes.
Same way we're going to resolve it in the United States.
Situations are going to get so bad that people have to take care of themselves or kick the damn bucket and then they'll get busy taking care of themselves.
I think as long as they can sit on their backside and howl and somebody comes and brings the bucket with some food in it, they'll howl.
When the guy stops bringing the bucket, pretty soon they'll get up and start stirring around a little bit.
In the meantime, they'll threaten you about the communists and threaten you about the devil and about anything else that you think of.
An honest answer to your question, I don't know, but I think really that is the answer.
You're going to have to make them do for themselves or starve.
Same as you're going to have to do to us.
Now as the air planner, what particular problems did you have?

During this time for these three years, it's one of the most dynamic times in American foreign policy, and we're going to talk about a lot of these things that happened and what impact they had on plans, but were there internal problems that you faced?
Internal armed services, you mean?
Yes, there were some really severe internal problems, some that
Of course, one of the big ones, I would imagine, is the Army and the Air Force breaking away.
Yes, that was not as big as some others.
What were some of the others?
That was a big one.
Well, right after the war, I guess it had three things that had happened that opened a lot of people's eyes and opened a lot of new horizons.
Atomic energy had come into being, of course.
And it had come in as an air weapon, the first application of it.
Air power had demonstrated its potential in such a manner, it demonstrated it before, but this time nobody could argue about it.
So, everybody wanted it.
You didn't have to sell yourself anymore as an airman.
You had to just keep from being taken over by somebody.
The other thing, in spite of the glory and all of the Battle of Ladygolf and whatnot, the total effects of the war,

said to you that the surface maybe as such just doesn't have any place left in the world as a combat unfair i don't i don't mean by that that you won't ever have any more submarines or anything like this but uh
Battleships and cruisers and these kind of things, they're fresh out.
You couldn't build them as fast as somebody could sink them.
Air Force was trying to get out from under.
It had been for a long time.
Long enough that I was already long before this one up for court martial twice on the subject.

And so everyone in moving forward from there was trying to put their best foot forward in terms of having the responsibility for air power operations of any type allocated to their service, the Army, Navy.
and of course Air Force fighting to be a separate force and not to let all those things be taken away.
And as far as Navy is concerned, I guess the thing peaked in the B-36 controversy.
All of which was kind of silly.
The B-36 didn't have a hell of a lot to do with it.
It was the
a mighty fine piece of equipment for what it made for, but by the time we're talking about it here, it's already ten years out of date.
But it served as a vehicle to get all these things all mulched up and out of focus before the public and the Congress.
And to make some real enemies out of, between Air Force and Navy, Naval Aviation in particular.
And so anything you did on a joint planning, as soon as you got to the air power part of that plan, you were going to have a hell of a fight.
And you had to fight with the Navy and you had to fight with the Air Force.
The Marines kind of acquiesced because the Navy agreed they could keep their limited amount of air, and that's all they wanted anyway, so they had relative peace, but the rest of us didn't.
And so that permeated this whole three years of fighting on the joint staff.
Nuclear-wise, of course, everybody wanted to be supreme in the nuclear thing.
The Navy wanted to drive its ships, to drive its airplanes, to be the best in the delivery of the weapons and everything else.
and of course the Air Force knew that that was its destiny and it would have it.
The Army couldn't be left out.
It needed its short range missiles, its guns, which it got of course.
And the big fight in there between the Air Force and the Army was over domination of the intercontinental
And who was going to dominate it?
The Air Force won out on that one, primarily.
It doesn't mean the Army can't do it, but they won that battle.
And I think we won on the Navy, too, because we outperformed them.
This is what made it so hard for me as the commander of the Joint Task Force
going to detonate the first nuclear weapon at high altitude as commander of the task force.
I had to go pick an Army missile to carry my warhead up there because the Air Force didn't have one.
That must have caused a lot of friction.
Well, it caused an awful lot of people in the Air Force to feel mighty hard at me.
because of course the people who had the Air Force missile were quite confident it could get there.
I had to be more than quite confident.
I had to be god damn near certain.
And the only reason the Army had one is because they brought Bonbon and his V-2 over here and it was that V-2 rocket that I used to put it up there.
Well we're going to get to that.
I was interested in
Besides the Intercontinentals and the B-36 controversy, what impacted the Russian atomic bomb in 1949 having the Air Force?
The Russian?
When Russia exploded their atomic bomb in 1949.
Did that change the plans?
That's really awfully hard to say.
No, I don't think so.
It put more urgency on some things.
Remember this took everybody by surprise.
Our experts said that they weren't going to have one until about 1960.
Yes, but we didn't all share that.
Oh, you didn't?
No, we didn't.
I didn't for one.
I was in the, by that time, in the atomic energy business.
John Vandenberg didn't share that view.
I think there were a number that didn't share it.
So, when they got it, it wasn't as much of a surprise to us as a question of what is the best thing to do in light of that fact.
We didn't have a ballistic missile that could get there.
And that's when we sat down with Bennett Shriver and said, we've got to make some compromises and then not change our mind.
And so that gave birth to our first intercontinental, truly intercontinental missile that could carry a significant warhead.
And we went ahead with it.
And we had it in time.
We had it before the Russians could really take advantage of their newfound strength, even in the sense of posing a real threat.
But Schriever did a damn good job of getting that rocket warhead combination together and getting it on the launch pads.
So I think that probably that was the biggest effect I had strictly on Air Force, not on the U.S., but on the Air Force.
Sure.
And that was urgency.
Yeah.
And we, I think, were relatively well prepared to go ahead.
And nobody was well prepared with all the reduction in funds and whatnot we'd have.
Oh, yeah.
but we were prepared to go ahead.

The other thing I think it did, the other impact that it had indirectly on the Air Force was evident in that day in July, I believe it was, 49 when Truman said we were going ahead with the hydrogen bomb.
At that time I was in the military liaison committee.
I was out of the joint chief.
So I wrote the draft press release that the president turned loose that afternoon.
Did you?
No kidding.
The general advisory committee to the Atomic Energy Commission.
had been meeting, well, for several days.
And they had made their recommendations to the President through the commission, of course.
And I was the Executive Secretary of the Military Liaison Committee, which was
a group that's supposed to protect the interests of, or represent, not protect, the interests of the Department of Defense with the Atomic Energy Commission.
And the chairman of that committee was a man named Webster, Bill Webster, who was president of New England Power and Life.
He's the guy that put the Yankee one, Yankee two reactors in up there later on.
And Bill was going over with the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs and Secretary of Defense and Chairman of the Commission.
And had met with the President the day before on the problem to present the, or to let the Chairman of the
General Advisory Committee present their views.
And so they were going back again this time and go over the thing with the President and he was going to, hopefully he was going to make a decision.
So the five of them were going over to the White House.
I wrote up the draft press release on the basis that he was going to say, yes, we are
which I thought he was, I'm going to say, and went along with Bill over there to the White House to the meeting.
Now, I didn't go in the Oval Office where they were meeting at that time, but I was just outside the door.
And when the President announced his decision in there,
But Bill came out and I gave him the draft press release and the president came to the door and read it and said, yeah that's right, roll it.
So, we went from there.
And that was a great day, I thought, because we almost did not go ahead with that because of all the guilty consciences, I think, that people had.
Like the General Advisory Committee.
Okay, now one of the guilty conscience, of course, was Oppenheimer.
Well, it was right there.
He was one of them.
And what was your, what was your, you know, he's a so-called father of the A-bomb.
Of course, he isn't a father, but he was one of the men instrumental in the development of the atomic bomb, and he was against the H-bomb.
What was your feeling toward him?
Well, I guess that's probably the hardest question that you could ask.
I got to know Oppenheimer when he was head of or member of the General Advisory Committee and when I was in the MLC.
I got to know him a lot better than that with the passage of time.
After I left that job, I went to defense as director of the Atomic Energy Committee of the Research and Development of the Department of Defense, under the Secretary of Defense.
And Appiah was chairman of that committee, so I worked directly for him during that period of time.
And my job, of course, to keep the damn place running.
I mean, that wasn't his occupation.
He was coming there on part-time doing these things.
Mine was to keep it, conceive the programs, get them approved, and get them implemented, and have the services and whatever other agencies of the government were involved do them.
So I didn't know what I was doing.
Arthur, I believe, had the most brilliant brain of any one that, that I would possibly have known.
It may have been so brilliant that I don't even know it, that I don't even know what it was thinking, you see.
I know this sounds silly, but I think it was that way.
I think he saw in his own mind so far down the road of history here, and he did things today that fit that pattern a hundred years from now in his mind.
Now, I'm not sure how you do this, because I've never tried to make my daily actions conform to something that I think will be or ought to be 50 or 100 years from now.
So I'm not sure whether it takes a brilliant mind or not, but I would certainly think it does.
And I believe that's what he did.
And I think he did a damn good job of it.
He always did or seemed to try to do the very best for the United States in the problem at hand, meaning its immediate effect.
Whether he was trying to do the best for it in the long range, I have some very serious questions in my mind.
because I think what he had in mind was a society, an objective in mind was a society that does not now exist.
Neither ours, nor the communist, nor socialism, or anything else.
And it was never
possible for me to get a clear enough picture of what that society was in his mind to frame it into something I could see.
But that feeling was always there after a year's association with him, for example.
and he was very genuine and very sincere about everything.
Yet, in that way of mind, there seemed to be a, an area, naive area that either things just weren't important to him, or
that he had no thought experience about, that he just let shine, didn't make any difference.
In his earlier trials and tribulations with the Atomic Energy Commission over the clearance problem, he had
no brilliant man would do the things that he did that caused the question on his security clearance.
And yet he never did see that it was stupid, or he certainly never did acknowledge it.
So why the hell did he do it, you see?
If I take that little problem, it didn't turn out to be so damn little, but relatively
and translate it up here to these bigger things, it looks still the same way, you see.
How come he thinks just this way?
Because he doesn't tell you, no more than he defended why he did it then.
So, I really never did know.
I don't know right now, just exactly what to think.
As a physicist, he was certainly a brilliant man, no question about that.

And if you look at what, try to put a little more meaning into what I'm saying here, if you take his position on the H-bomb, I know he knew, in retrospect I know he knew, that it was physically possible to do it.
that certainly we could get fusion and we could make it work and we could control it.
He must have known that we couldn't sit here and not do it and have the Russians do it and hold it over our head.
He just must have known that.
He never said that, but he must have.
So, why did he take that position?
Is it because he feared retribution by God?
I don't believe so.
I don't believe he believed any of that.
So, you just end up with a bunch of damn questions and not many answers.
So, I don't know.
Did you ever have, I mean, working for him like that, did you ever ask him straight out, why do you support your, how do you support your position?
It never, the answer is yes, I have, a lot of times, but I'm talking about something factual, something immediate.
And he always had a rational answer.
And sometimes I agreed with it, sometimes I didn't, but it was at least on the basis of tangible things that you could consider.
You ask him about these kind of long-range things that I'm talking about, or philosophical things,
he could look right at you and talk a whole batch of sentences and not tell you a goddamn thing and move on to the next problem.
And without your feeling that he was trying to be deceptive.
I don't know yet whether he was or not.
He was a very complex man.
How was he as far as an administrator?
No, he wasn't.
He didn't profess to be an administrator.
He didn't really want to be.
How was he dealing with people?
With his peers?
Okay.
I think you have to, when they ask that about that particular man, that particular time, we have to look at one, remember one other thing.
and it sounds maybe even unbecoming of me to mention it.
But right after the bomb went off, an atomic fusion had been achieved by the United States, and it had won the war in the Pacific.
The people who had worked on it, who had mastered this
And they would do a lot of credit.
It was a wonderful job.
But they had not had any praise.
And they were hungry.
And they drank it in.
And they became a fraternity.
And if you were a member of that fraternity, brother, you could do no wrong.
If you were not a member of that fraternity, it didn't make a damn what you thought.
Nobody listened.
You couldn't even speak their language.
Well, it was at that point, under that circumstances, that I entered the field, not a member of the fraternity.
And after five years, I guess, or six, I'll have to check it, of working with the military side of the nuclear business, I became the general manager of the Atomic Energy Commission.
The great scientists are wonderful people, and even though they are members of this exclusive fraternity,
they get hungry just like everybody else does.
They like to have three meals a day and ride airplanes and all kinds of things.
So they need some money.
The Atomic Energy Commission was the only place they had to get any money at that time.
So they at least have to be civil to the guy who gives them the money.
So I got to know a lot of them.
some very well, and some of them very wonderful people.
But I got to know a great deal about the motives and egos and all the other things that make them tick.
I didn't remember all kinds of funny things about them.
One of the most wonderful people in that fraternity is one that didn't
to create such a fraternity to be the last thing he wanted to do.
And I haven't heard from him in about a year.
I don't know whether he's still alive or not.
Dr. Eugene Wigner from Princeton.
Absolutely wonderful man.
Wonderful physicist and scientist, but also a very wonderful man.
He's the one that when they were working
